questions.text: Identify the image shown below? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Maxillary sinusitis

 

Explanation: 

 

The CT image shows maxillary sinusitis because:

 

  • Clear hypodense thickening in the maxillary sinus
  • Involvement of maxillary sinus with mucosal thickening/opacification
  • Anatomical landmarks visible: 
    • Orbit above
    • Maxillary sinus below
    • Ethmoid cells medially
    • Cribriform plate superiorly
  • Disease appears to be spreading into nasal cavity, suggesting possible antrochoanal polyp

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Frontal sinusitis

 

  • Frontal sinuses not clearly visible in this cut
  • Would be located superior to orbits
  • Different radiological appearance

 

Option C. Ethmoidal sinusitis

 

  • Though ethmoid cells are visible medially
  • No significant pathology in ethmoid region
  • Would show opacification of ethmoid air cells

 

Option D. Sphenoidal sinusitis

 

  • Sphenoid sinus not visible in this cut
  • Would be seen at nasopharyngeal level
  • Located most posteriorly among all sinuses

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Most common in adults because ostium locates higher than floor level and drainage is against the gravity.
  • Pain over upper jaw present.

choices.text: Increase dose of haloperidol
Change haloperidol to clozapine
Give fluphenzine instead of haloperidol

questions.text: A patient of Schizophrenia was started on antipsychotic drug haloperidol. Few hours later, he presented with torticollis and muscular dystonia. What is the next best step for the management of this patient? (Fmge Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Give benztropine

 

When a patient on haloperidol develops extrapyramidal symptoms (EPS) like torticollis and muscular dystonia, the next best step is typically to administer an anticholinergic medication like benzhexol or benztropine to alleviate these side effects. Increasing the dose of haloperidol would likely worsen the EPS, while changing to clozapine is an option for patients with severe EPS or a history of non-response to other treatments. Fluphenazine is unlikely to be significantly different from haloperidol in causing EPS.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increase dose of haloperidol: Increasing the dose of haloperidol is not the appropriate response when a patient develops extrapyramidal symptoms (EPS) such as torticollis and muscular dystonia. It can exacerbate these side effects.

 

Option B. Change haloperidol to clozapine: Clozapine is an atypical antipsychotic that is less likely to cause EPS compared to typical antipsychotics like haloperidol. Switching to clozapine can be a reasonable option to manage EPS.

 

Option C. Give fluphenzine instead of haloperidol: Fluphenazine is another typical antipsychotic and is not expected to be significantly different from haloperidol in terms of causing EPS. Switching to fluphenazine may not effectively address the EPS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Benztropine is an anticholinergic medication commonly used to manage extrapyramidal symptoms (EPS) caused by antipsychotic medications. It can be an appropriate choice to alleviate the torticollis and muscular dystonia.

questions.text: Salter Harris Type 1 injury passes through which zone?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hypertrophic zone 

 

SALTER HARRIS CLASSIFICATION 

  • The arrangement of cells of the physis is in layers or zones. 
  • These layers include the reserve, proliferative and hypertrophic zones. 
  • The reserve zone serves as the storage area for lipids, proteoglycans, and glycogen for growth and matrix production later. 
  • The proliferative zone has the highest rate of extracellular matrix production and accounts for the most abundant longitudinal growth. 
  • The hypertrophic zone has three phases: 
    • Maturation allows for preparation for calcification
    • Degenerative further prepare the matrix
    • Provisional calcification zone is where chondrocyte death occurs, allowing for calcium release. 
  • Physeal fractures most commonly occur in the zone of provisional calcification, as it is the weakest in response to shearing stress. 
  • The physis is weaker than ligaments or periosteum in children, causing injury to the growth plate before other structures. 
  • Zones of physis:

 

 

 

  • Salter and Harris described two major types of epiphyseal plates: the pressure epiphysis and the traction epiphysis. 
  • Pressure epiphyses provide longitudinal growth, at the end of long bones, are intra-articular, and bear weight. 
  • Traction epiphyses provide appositional growth, at the origin or insertion of muscles, are extra-articular, and do not bear weight. 
  • Their classification focuses on injuries at pressure epiphyses. 
  • They recognized that physeal fractures consistently occur through the same histologic plane called the zone of provisional calcification. 
  • This zone, located in the zone of hypertrophy, represents a transitional point between calcified and non-calcified extracellular matrix proteins, making it weaker than its surrounding osseous-ligamentous structures, and therefore more susceptible to injury.

 

 

  • In type I injury, there is slip of epiphysis with damage to the hypertrophic zone of the physis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Resting zone: It is affected in storage disorders like Gaucher’s disease. 

 

Option B. Proliferative zone: It is affected in growth hormone defects like Larsen’s syndrome. 

 

Option D. Zone of provisional calcification: It is affected in mineralization defects like rickets. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hypertrophic zone of the physis has a high bone turnover. 
  • It is the area where all Salter-Harris injuries occur. 
  • Thus, the Type I injuries occurs in the hypertrophic zone of the physis.

questions.text: Identify the marked structure:(INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Posterior rib

 

The marked structure in the provided chest X-ray image points to the horizontal part of the rib, which is indicative of the posterior rib. In radiographic anatomy, the posterior ribs are visualized as horizontal structures on a chest X-ray, whereas the anterior ribs appear more curved as they wrap around the thoracic cavity. This distinction is crucial for identifying the ribs accurately.

 

The posterior ribs are highlighted because they are flatter and more horizontal compared to the anterior ribs, which curve forward.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anterior rib: The anterior ribs are more curved and not horizontal like the posterior ribs. The marked structure clearly shows a horizontal rib, which excludes the anterior rib as the correct answer.

 

Option C. Costal cartilage: Costal cartilage does not show up on standard X-rays because it is not as radiopaque as bone. Therefore, it cannot be the marked structure.

 

Option D. Pulmonary artery: The pulmonary artery would appear in the lung hilum and would not resemble the horizontal rib structure. Thus, it is not the correct answer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The posterior rib appears as a horizontal structure on a chest X-ray, distinguishing it from the more curved anterior ribs and other thoracic structures.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis based on the CT image? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) PUJO (Pelviureteric Junction Obstruction)

 

The CT image shows a massively dilated renal pelvis with thinning of the renal parenchyma, which is characteristic of Pelviureteric Junction Obstruction (PUJO). In PUJO, the obstruction occurs at the junction between the renal pelvis and the ureter, causing the pelvis to become disproportionately dilated compared to the calyces. This results in significant thinning of the renal tissue, which is evident in the image. The appearance of a stretched and thin parenchyma alongside a dilated pelvis points towards PUJO.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.  Renal cyst: A renal cyst typically appears as a single, fluid-filled, well-defined lesion within the kidney. The key feature is that it would appear as a solitary or few non-communicating cysts, unlike the diffuse dilation and thin parenchyma seen in PUJO.

 

Option C.  AD PCKD (Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease): AD PCKD is characterized by multiple cysts throughout the kidney, which are typically non-communicating and cause the kidneys to become enlarged and lobulated. In contrast, the CT here shows a single, large, dilated pelvis rather than multiple distinct cysts.

 

Option D.  Horseshoe kidney: A horseshoe kidney is a congenital condition where the kidneys are fused at the lower poles, forming a horseshoe shape. It does not present with significant pelvis dilation or obstructive features as seen in this CT image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

PUJO is characterized by massive dilation of the renal pelvis with thinning of the renal parenchyma due to obstruction at the pelviureteric junction. The pelvis is more dilated than the calyces, which is a hallmark finding on imaging.

questions.text: The remnants of Wolffian ducts in females are located in? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Leaves of broad ligament

 

Explanation:

 

Leaves of broad ligament:

 

  • The Wolffian ducts, also known as mesonephric ducts, form the male genital tract in men.
  • In females, the Mullerian duct forms the female internal genitalia, including the fallopian tubes, uterus, and the upper part of the vagina, while the Wolffian ducts atrophy.
  • As the Wolffian ducts atrophy in females, they leave behind remnants located between the two layers of the broad ligament and in the anterolateral wall of the vagina. These remnants include:
    • Hydatid cyst of Morgagni: Located lateral to the fallopian tube.
    • Koblet’s tubules: Found in the outer part of the broad ligament.
    • Epoophoron: Located between the ovary and the fallopian tube.
    • Para-oophoron: Situated between the ovary and the uterus.
    • Gartner’s duct: Located in the anterolateral wall of the vagina.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pouch of Douglas: This is the rectouterine pouch, a space between the uterus and the rectum, and is not associated with remnants of the Wolffian ducts.

 

Option C. Uterovesical pouch: This is the space between the uterus and the bladder and does not contain Wolffian duct remnants.

 

Option D. Iliac fossa: This is an anatomical region of the pelvis, and it is not related to the remnants of the Wolffian ducts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The remnants of the Wolffian ducts in females are found in the leaves of the broad ligament and the anterolateral wall of the vagina.

 

Ref: Page no 47, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient came to ED with complaints of weakness, paresthesia, and breathing difficulty. Relevant investigations were done. The ECG obtained is suggestive of: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Hypokalemia

 

History suggestive of cramps, muscle weakness is common in hypokalemia. ECG shows PR, QTc prolongation, T wave inversion, u waves. “NikEleKam T waves aka reverse wellen sign” seen in Hypokalemia

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hyperkalemia: Typically, hyperkalemia would show peaked T waves, widened QRS complexes, and possibly a flattened P wave, which are not evident in this ECG.

 

Option C. Hypocalcemia: Would more typically show a prolonged QT interval but lacks the specific U wave features seen in hypokalemia.

 

Option D. Hypercalcemia: This condition would likely show a shortened QT interval, which is not present in this ECG.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ECG Findings in Hypokalemia:

 

  • U-waves
  • Prolonged QTc
  • Flattened/inverted Ts
  • Sagging ST
  • ST Depression
  • Biphasic t-waves
  • ST elevation in aVR
  • PVCs/Ventricular Dysrhythmias
  • Pseudo-ischemic patterns

questions.text: A 10-year-old male child presented with the following finding. What’s your diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Limbal dermoid


A limbal dermoid is a benign congenital lesion often present at birth. It typically appears at the limbus, the border area between the cornea and the sclera, and is composed of dense connective tissue that can sometimes contain hair follicles or even teeth remnants.

 

The image shows a mass at the limbus, which is characteristic of a limbal dermoid. These lesions are non-cancerous and can sometimes cause astigmatism or irritation depending on their size and location.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Papilloma: This option is incorrect because papillomas are epithelial tumors that usually present as small, fleshy, or warty growths on the conjunctiva. They do not typically appear as large, dense masses at the limbus.

 

Option C. Pyogenic granuloma: This is incorrect as pyogenic granulomas are fast-growing lesions that are often red, vascular, and prone to bleeding. They result from an inflammatory response and are usually not located at the limbus.

 

Option D. Pinguecula: Pingueculae are yellowish, slightly raised lesions located on the conjunctiva, usually near the nasal or temporal side of the cornea. They are associated with elastotic degeneration and do not encroach on the limbus.

 

Educational Objective:


A limbal dermoid is a congenital, benign growth located at the limbus, often containing connective tissue, hair, or teeth remnants, distinguishing it from other ocular lesions.

questions.text: A lady died under unnatural death within 3 years of marriage. Who will do the inquest? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Magistrate

 

Explanation:

 

Magistrate inquest is mandatory in cases of dowry death, which is defined as:

 

  • Death of a woman within 7 years of marriage
  • Death is unnatural
  • Death has association with dowry allegations This comes under Section 196 BNSS (previously 176 CrPC) and is one of the three specific conditions requiring magistrate inquest along with custodial deaths and exhumation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Police: Incorrect Police inquest (194 BNSS) is not permitted in dowry death cases due to their sensitive nature and to ensure impartial investigation.

 

Option C. Advocate: Incorrect Advocates are not authorized to conduct inquests. They may represent parties in legal proceedings but cannot conduct death investigations.

 

Option D. Coroner: Incorrect Coroner system is not practiced in India. It was previously followed in some cities like Mumbai but has been abolished. Coroner system is currently practiced in countries like UK and USA.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Identify the X-ray shown below. (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pulmonary edema

 

Explanation:

 

The chest X-ray demonstrates the classic "bat wing" appearance characteristic of pulmonary edema. This pattern shows:

 

  • Bilateral hilar infiltrates with a perihilar distribution
  • Butterfly or bat-wing-shaped opacity
  • Edema fluid accumulation in the interstitial and alveolar spaces due to:
    • Increased hydrostatic pressure in the pulmonary circulation (e.g., left heart failure)
    • Increased capillary permeability

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pleural effusion: Incorrect

 

  • Typically shows blunting of the costophrenic angles with a meniscus sign
  • The pattern seen here is more central and perihilar, rather than at the lung bases

 

Option B. Pulmonary fibrosis: Incorrect

 

  • Pulmonary fibrosis shows reticular opacities, honeycombing, and traction bronchiectasis
  • The pattern is usually peripheral and basal, not central and perihilar

 

Option D. Hydrothorax: Incorrect

 

  • A pleural effusion containing transudative fluid
  • Would show a meniscus sign and blunting of costophrenic angles, rather than a central bat-wing distribution

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize the classic "bat wing" or "butterfly" pattern on chest X-ray as characteristic of pulmonary edema, which presents as bilateral perihilar infiltrates with a central distribution.

choices.text: Fracture of the Shaft of Humerus
Fracture of the Shaft of Femur

questions.text: Gallow’s traction is primarily used for which of the following conditions? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Fracture of the Shaft of Femur

 

Gallows traction is primarily used for fractures of the shaft of femur in infants and very young children (typically under 2 years of age). In this traction method, both lower limbs are suspended vertically from overhead with the hips flexed to 90 degrees, regardless of which femur is fractured. This position allows for proper alignment of the femoral fracture while permitting diaper changes and nursing care. The child's body weight provides the counterforce for the traction.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Perthes' Disease is treated with various methods to maintain the femoral head within the acetabulum, including abduction braces, casting, or surgical containment, but Gallows traction is not typically used for this condition.

 

Option B: Fractures of the humeral shaft in children are typically treated with hanging arm casts, coaptation splints, or functional bracing. Overhead traction like Gallows traction would not be appropriate for upper extremity fractures.

 

Option D: Pelvic fractures in children are usually treated with bed rest, analgesics, and mobilization as tolerated. More severe fractures might require external fixation or open reduction, but Gallows traction is not used for pelvic fractures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gallows traction is a specific type of skin traction used for femoral shaft fractures in very young children that suspends both legs vertically, utilizing the child's body weight as counter-traction while allowing for easy care and diaper changes.

questions.text: A young female patient complains of low back pain radiating to the right hip, back of the thigh, leg, and ankle after an intense workout of lifting some heavy weights. MRI shows the following finding. Which nerve root is most likely to be involved here? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) L5

 

The MRI provided shows a disc prolapse between the L4 and L5 vertebrae, which is a common site for disc herniation. In cases of disc herniation, the exiting nerve root is generally affected. The L5 nerve root is compressed in a typical L4-L5 disc prolapse, as the L5 nerve exits below the L5 vertebra. Disc herniations are usually postero-lateral, meaning the herniated material presses on the nerve root exiting the spinal cord below the level of the disc.

 

In this case, the symptoms described — radiating pain down the back of the thigh, leg, and ankle — are consistent with L5 nerve root involvement, as the L5 nerve innervates muscles in this area and also provides sensory innervation to the same region.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. S1: An S1 nerve root compression typically causes symptoms in the posterior leg and into the foot, especially affecting the lateral aspects of the foot and possibly the sole. This distribution is less aligned with the symptoms of the patient described, which are more characteristic of an L5 nerve root involvement.

 

Option B. L3: An L3 nerve root compression would cause pain in the front of the thigh, which is not the primary area of concern in this case. The patient’s symptoms include pain radiating to the posterior leg, more aligned with the L5 nerve.

 

Option C. L4: While an L4 nerve root can sometimes be compressed, this usually happens with a far-lateral disc herniation, which is less common than a postero-lateral disc herniation. The described pain in the back of the thigh, leg, and ankle is not typically associated with L4 nerve root compression.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In an L4-L5 disc prolapse, the L5 nerve root is most commonly compressed, causing pain radiating down the back of the thigh and into the leg and ankle.

questions.text: What is the primary function of ghrelin? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Increase appetite

 

Explanation:


Ghrelin functions primarily as an appetite stimulant. It is often referred to as the "hunger hormone" because it signals the brain to increase food intake. Ghrelin levels typically rise before meals and fall after eating, playing a key role in meal initiation. This hormone is produced predominantly by specialized cells in the stomach lining.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option a. Stimulate water absorption - Ghrelin is not involved in water absorption in the gastrointestinal tract. Water absorption is primarily regulated by other mechanisms including osmotic gradients and hormones like aldosterone.
  • Option c. Regulation of temperature - Ghrelin does not play a significant role in thermoregulation. Body temperature is primarily regulated by the hypothalamus and various other hormones.
  • Option d. Stimulate lipogenesis - While ghrelin may have some metabolic effects, stimulating lipogenesis is not its primary function. Hormones like insulin play a much more significant role in promoting fat storage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ghrelin is a peptide hormone that serves as a physiological signal for hunger, working in opposition to satiety hormones like Peptide YY to regulate energy balance and food intake.

choices.text: Between the buccopharyngeal fascia and alar fascia
Between the prevertebral fascia and alar fascia
Between the buccopharyngeal fascia and prevertebral fascia

questions.text: Where is the danger space in the neck located? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: b) Between the prevertebral fascia and alar fascia

 

Explanation:

 

The danger space in the neck is located between the prevertebral fascia and alar fascia. The alar fascia is an ancillary layer of deep cervical fascia which divides the retropharyngeal space into two parts. The posterior space between the alar fascia and prevertebral fascia is specifically called the "dangerous space in neck." This space is clinically significant because infections in this space can spread from the base of the skull to the mediastinum, as it has no anatomical barriers in the inferior direction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option a) Between the buccopharyngeal fascia and alar fascia - This space is the anterior part of the retropharyngeal space, not the danger space itself.

 

Option c) Between the buccopharyngeal fascia and prevertebral fascia - This constitutes the entire retropharyngeal space, which is divided by the alar fascia into anterior and posterior components, with only the posterior component being the danger space.

 

Option d) None of the above - This is incorrect as option b correctly identifies the danger space location.

 

Education Objective: 

 

The danger space, located between the prevertebral fascia and alar fascia in the posterior part of the retropharyngeal space, is clinically important because infections here can spread extensively from the skull base to the mediastinum due to lack of inferior anatomical barriers.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a tributary of the thoracic duct? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: d. Right jugular trunk

 

 

Explanation:

 

The right jugular trunk is not a tributary of the thoracic duct. Instead, it drains into the right lymphatic duct. The thoracic duct receives lymph from roughly both halves of the body below the diaphragm and the left half above the diaphragm. At the root of the neck, it receives the left jugular trunk (from nodes in the neck), the left subclavian trunk (from nodes in the axilla), and the left bronchomediastinal trunk (which drains lymph from the left half of the thorax).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Left lumbar trunk: This is a tributary of the thoracic duct. It brings lymph from the lower limb and pelvis on the left side and contributes to the formation of the cisterna chyli, which is the beginning of the thoracic duct.

 

Option B. Right lumbar trunk: Despite being on the right side, this is also a tributary of the thoracic duct. It contributes to the formation of the cisterna chyli and helps drain lymph from the right lower limb and abdomen.

 

Option C. Left jugular trunk: This is a tributary of the thoracic duct. It drains lymph from the left side of the head and neck and joins the thoracic duct near its termination.

 

Education Objective: 

 

 

The thoracic duct receives lymph from both lower limbs and abdomen, and from the left side of the thorax, left upper limb, and left side of head and neck, while the right jugular trunk drains to the right lymphatic duct.

questions.text: A young patient undergoing treatment for multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB) presents with symptoms of weight gain, cold intolerance, and lethargy. Laboratory investigations reveal high levels of thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) and low levels of T3 (triiodothyronine) and T4 (thyroxine). Which of the following drugs is likely responsible for these symptoms? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ethionamide.

 

Ethionamide, a second-line antitubercular agent used in the treatment of MDR-TB, is known to cause hypothyroidism as a side effect. This condition is characterized by an underactive thyroid gland, leading to symptoms such as weight gain, cold intolerance, and lethargy. The laboratory findings of elevated TSH and low levels of T3 and T4 further support this diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cycloserine: Cycloserine is used in the treatment of MDR-TB, but its side effects are more commonly neurological, including mood changes and seizures. It is not typically associated with thyroid dysfunction.

 

Option C. Streptomycin: Streptomycin, an aminoglycoside antibiotic, is used in TB treatment and is known for its potential ototoxicity and nephrotoxicity, rather than effects on thyroid function.

 

Option D. Pyrazinamide: Pyrazinamide is a first-line anti-TB medication. Its side effects include hepatotoxicity and hyperuricemia but not typically hypothyroidism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ethionamide, a second-line drug used in the treatment of multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB), can cause hypothyroidism, characterized by symptoms such as weight gain, cold intolerance, lethargy, elevated TSH, and low T3 and T4 levels.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with gums bleeding, hepatosplenomegaly has a peripheral smear finding shown in the image. Flow cytometry was ordered for patient and CD19, CD22 and TdT came to be positive. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) ALL B Lymphocyte Type

 

This is a case of B-cell Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (B-ALL) based on:

 

1. Clinical presentation:

 

  • Young child (5 years old)
  • Gum bleeding (due to thrombocytopenia)
  • Hepatosplenomegaly

 

2. Peripheral smear:

 

  • Shows lymphoblasts with: 
    • Scanty agranular cytoplasm
    • Condensed chromatin
    • No abnormal granules

 

3. Flow cytometry findings:

 

  • Positive for:
    • CD19 (B-cell marker)
    • CD22 (B-cell marker)
    • TdT (terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase - immature lymphoid marker)

 

These markers are characteristic of B-cell ALL. Flow cytometry is the investigation of choice for confirming the diagnosis and lineage assignment

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. ALL T Lymphocyte Type

 

  • Incorrect because T-ALL would be positive for CD1, CD2, CD5, CD7 markers
  • Usually presents with mediastinal mass
  • Flow cytometry shows different markers than presented here

 

Option C. AML

 

  • Incorrect because myeloblasts would show Auer rods and granular cytoplasm
  • Would be positive for MPO/NSE markers
  • Different flow cytometry pattern

 

Option D. CML

 

  • Incorrect because CML shows mature granulocytes with left shift
  • Presents typically in adults
  • Positive for Philadelphia chromosome
  • Different flow cytometry pattern

 

Educational Objective:

 

B-cell ALL is characterized by lymphoblasts on peripheral smear and positivity for B-cell markers (CD19, CD22) and TdT on flow cytometry.

questions.text: Diagnose the condition shown in the following image.  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chronic osteomyelitis

 

CHRONIC OSTEOMYELITIS

 

  • Chronic Osteomyelitis is a long-standing infection of the bone that typically results from bacteria, most commonly staphylococcus aureus.
  • It is characterized by persistent pain, swelling, warmth, and redness over the affected area.
  • The infection often leads to chronic discharge from a sinus tract or wound, and systemic symptoms may be less pronounced compared to acute infections.
  • On radiographs or MRI, chronic osteomyelitis may present as:
    • Bone Destruction: There can be areas of bone destruction or loss with possible formation of sequestra (dead bone) and involucrum (new bone formation surrounding the dead bone).
    • Sinus Tracts: Imaging may show draining sinus tracts or soft tissue swelling.
    • Cortical Erosion: There might be cortical erosion or irregularity.

 

 

  • Histopathology: Chronic osteomyelitis is characterized by the presence of chronic inflammatory cells, granulation tissue, and sometimes necrotic bone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ewing’s Sarcoma: Ewing’s Sarcoma is a malignant bone tumor typically found in children and young adults. It is one of the small round blue cell tumors. Patients usually present with localized pain, swelling, and possibly systemic symptoms like fever. The tumor often affects long bones or the pelvis.  On radiographs or MRI, Ewing’s sarcoma can present as a permeative lesion with ill-defined margins, an onion skin periosteal reaction. It is typically associated with an extensive soft tissue mass, an osteolytic lesion with or without calcifications. Histopathologically, it is characterized by small round blue cells with a characteristic "small round cell" appearance and is often confirmed with immunohistochemical staining and cytogenetic analysis (e.g., EWS-FLI1 fusion gene).

 

 

Option C. Osteosarcoma: Osteosarcoma is a malignant bone tumor that primarily affects adolescents and young adults. It is characterized by pain, swelling, and occasionally a palpable mass. It is commonly located around the knee or the metaphysis of long bones. On radiographs or MRI, osteosarcoma may present as mixed osteolytic and osteoblastic (sclerotic) lesions, formation of new bone perpendicular to the cortex due to the aggressive nature of the tumor lifting the periosteum, called as Codman’s triangle, and a soft tissue mass. Histopathologically, it shows pleomorphic osteoblasts producing malignant osteoid or bone matrix. Diagnosis is confirmed through biopsy and histological examination.

 

Codman’s triangle

 

Option D. Acute Osteomyelitis: Acute Osteomyelitis is a recent infection of the bone, usually caused by bacteria. Symptoms include rapid onset of severe pain, swelling, redness, and warmth over the affected area, often accompanied by systemic symptoms like fever and malaise. On radiographs or MRI, acute osteomyelitis may not show significant bone changes initially, but can later show bone marrow edema and possible periosteal reaction. As the condition progresses, there may be evidence of bone destruction, sequestra formation, or an abscess. Histopathologically, it is typically characterized by acute inflammatory changes with neutrophils and potentially abscess formation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Chronic Osteomyelitis is characterized by long-standing infection, typically with a chronic clinical course and imaging findings that reflect bone destruction and chronic inflammation.
  • The given image in the question shows sequestrum and involucrum in the lower end of femur, which are typically characteristic of chronic osteomyelitis.

choices.text: Small dorsal part of the hypobranchial eminence

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a source of development for the tongue? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: d) 5th pharyngeal arch

 

Explanation:

 

The 5th pharyngeal arch is not a source of development for the tongue. In human embryology, the 5th pharyngeal arch actually disappears during development and does not contribute to any structures. The tongue develops from several other structures: the anterior two-thirds forms from the lingual swellings of the 1st arch and possibly the tuberculum impar, while the posterior one-third develops from the cranial part of the hypobranchial eminence (related to the 3rd arch). The musculature of the tongue derives from occipital myotomes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Lingual swellings of the 1st arch - This is a correct source. The lingual swellings (two lateral lingual swellings) of the 1st pharyngeal arch fuse in the midline to form the anterior two-thirds of the tongue, making this answer incorrect as the question asks for what is NOT a source.

 

Option B) Occipital myotomes - This is a correct source. The musculature of the tongue develops from occipital myotomes, which explains why the tongue muscles are innervated by the hypoglossal nerve (XII). This is a true developmental source, making this answer incorrect for the question.

 

Option C) Small dorsal part of the hypobranchial eminence - This is a correct source. The posterior one-third of the tongue develops from the cranial part of the hypobranchial eminence, which is related to the 3rd pharyngeal arch. This is a true developmental source, making this answer incorrect for the question.

 

 

Education Objective: 

 

The tongue has complex embryological origins from multiple structures including the 1st arch lingual swellings, the 3rd arch via the hypobranchial eminence, and occipital myotomes for its musculature, but not from the 5th pharyngeal arch which disappears during development.

questions.text: A patient after RTA (Road Traffic Accident) presented with hypovolemic shock. What is the reason for decreased cardiac output in this patient? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Decreased preload

 

Hypovolemic shock, often caused by significant blood loss as in the case of a road traffic accident (RTA), leads to a decrease in the volume of blood returning to the heart (preload). Preload is the initial stretching of the cardiac myocytes prior to contraction, which is directly related to the volume of blood filling the heart. When there is a significant loss of blood volume, the preload decreases, leading to a reduced stroke volume and, consequently, decreased cardiac output.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased afterload: This refers to the resistance the heart must overcome to eject blood. Increased afterload is not a primary issue in hypovolemic shock.

 

Option C. High systemic vascular resistance: This would be more characteristic of distributive shock, such as septic shock, rather than hypovolemic shock.

 

Option D. Decreased contractility: While decreased contractility can reduce cardiac output, in hypovolemic shock, the primary problem is the loss of blood volume leading to decreased preload, not a primary issue with the heart muscle's ability to contract.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In hypovolemic shock, the primary cause of decreased cardiac output is decreased preload due to significant loss of blood volume.

questions.text: A study was undertaken to estimate the effect of a drug ‘D’ in three different groups – Plants, Animals, and Human beings. Samples were chosen randomly out of the three groups individually. This is a type of? [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Stratified random sampling

 

Stratified random sampling is a sampling method where the total population is divided into homogeneous subgroups (strata) based on specific characteristics, and then random samples are taken from each stratum. In this question, the total population consists of three different groups: plants, animals, and humans, each forming a distinct stratum. After forming these strata, random sampling is conducted within each group to select samples, ensuring representation from all subgroups.

 

This approach ensures that the study includes balanced and proportional representation of each group, reflecting the actual composition of the population.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Simple random sampling: Simple random sampling involves selecting individuals purely by chance from the entire population without dividing it into subgroups. In this scenario, samples are taken from specific groups rather than randomly from the entire population.

 

Option B. Systematic random sampling: This method involves selecting samples from a population at regular intervals (e.g., every nth member). This technique is not used here as the sampling is done within defined groups, not systematically across the whole population.

 

Option D. Cluster random sampling: In cluster sampling, the population is divided into clusters (often geographically or by natural grouping), and entire clusters are randomly selected for study. In this question, the groups (plants, animals, humans) are not clusters but strata, making this option incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Stratified random sampling involves dividing a heterogeneous population into homogeneous subgroups and then conducting random sampling within each subgroup.

questions.text: A male patient presents to the emergency department. The arterial blood gas report is as follows: pH 7.2, pCO2 81mm Hg, and HCO3 40 mEq/L. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Respiratory acidosis

 

The arterial blood gas (ABG) report shows a pH of 7.2, which indicates acidosis (normal pH: 7.35-7.45). The partial pressure of carbon dioxide (pCO2) is elevated at 81 mm Hg (normal range: 35-45 mm Hg), indicating that the acidosis is due to a respiratory cause, as CO2 retention leads to respiratory acidosis.

 

The bicarbonate (HCO3) level is elevated at 40 mEq/L (normal range: 22-28 mEq/L). This elevation suggests that the kidneys are compensating for the respiratory acidosis by retaining bicarbonate to buffer the excess hydrogen ions, indicating a chronic component to the respiratory acidosis.

 

In summary, the primary disturbance is respiratory acidosis, evidenced by the elevated pCO2, and the elevated bicarbonate suggests a compensatory response by the kidneys, characteristic of chronic respiratory acidosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Respiratory alkalosis: Respiratory alkalosis is characterized by a high pH and low pCO2, which is the opposite of the findings in this ABG report.

 

Option B. Metabolic acidosis: Metabolic acidosis would present with a low pH and a low bicarbonate level. However, in this case, the bicarbonate is elevated, not decreased, indicating the primary issue is not metabolic acidosis.

 

Option D. Metabolic alkalosis: Metabolic alkalosis is characterized by a high pH and elevated bicarbonate, but without the accompanying high pCO2. The presence of high pCO2 and low pH indicates the primary disturbance is respiratory, not metabolic.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A blood gas report showing low pH and high pCO2 with compensatory elevated bicarbonate indicates respiratory acidosis, often with a chronic component if the bicarbonate is significantly elevated.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding increase in GFR? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increase renal perfusion

 

Glomerular filtration rate (GFR) is influenced by various factors, including the blood flow through the kidneys and the pressures within the glomerular capillaries. An increase in renal perfusion means an increase in blood flow to the kidneys, which enhances the filtration process and thereby increases the GFR. This can be achieved by dilation of the afferent arteriole (which increases blood flow into the glomerulus) or by constriction of the efferent arteriole (which increases the pressure within the glomerulus).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increase resistance of afferent arteriole: Increasing the resistance of the afferent arteriole means constricting it, which would reduce blood flow into the glomerulus and subsequently decrease the GFR.

 

Option B. Decrease resistance of efferent arteriole: Decreasing the resistance of the efferent arteriole means dilating it, allowing blood to flow out of the glomerulus more easily. This reduces the pressure within the glomerulus, leading to a decrease in GFR.

 

Option C. Increase Bowman capsule hydrostatic pressure: Increasing the hydrostatic pressure within the Bowman's capsule would oppose the filtration pressure, leading to a decrease in GFR rather than an increase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Increasing renal perfusion is the most effective way to increase the glomerular filtration rate (GFR).

questions.text: Which mutation is seen in sickle cell disease? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Glu → Val (6)

 

Sickle cell disease is caused by a specific point mutation at position 6 of the β-globin chain, where glutamic acid (Glu) is replaced by valine (Val). This single amino acid substitution leads to the formation of abnormal hemoglobin S (HbS), which polymerizes under deoxygenated conditions, causing red blood cells to become sickle-shaped.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sickle cell disease is caused by a point mutation at position 6 of the β-globin chain, where glutamic acid (Glu) is replaced by valine (Val).

questions.text: Identify the child whose growth is compromised: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Line C

 

The growth trajectory marked as "C" on the chart indicates compromised growth. This line is positioned below the 3rd percentile curve, which suggests that the child's weight for age is significantly below what is expected for her age, placing her in a category that may be indicative of undernutrition or an underlying health condition that is affecting her growth.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: This trajectory follows closely along the 50th percentile, indicating normal growth patterns according to WHO standards.

 

Option B: Although this trajectory starts near the 15th percentile, it remains consistently parallel to the standard growth curves, suggesting stable growth that remains proportionate over time, albeit at a lower percentile.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In pediatric health assessments, growth charts are critical tools. They help healthcare providers monitor a child's growth over time, comparing their progress against standardized percentile curves. A trajectory like "C", which falls below the 3rd percentile, warrants further investigation to determine the cause of the poor growth and to initiate appropriate interventions.

questions.text: Where is primary hematogenous osteomyelitis most commonly observed in children? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Metaphysis

 

Hematogenous osteomyelitis in children most commonly affects the metaphysis of long bones. This occurs due to the unique vascular arrangement in the metaphyseal region where blood vessels form a hair-pin loop arrangement, causing blood stasis. This anatomical feature makes the metaphysis a favorable site for bacteria to settle. The lower femoral metaphysis is the most frequently affected site, followed by upper tibial, upper femoral, and upper humeral metaphyses.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Epiphysis: The epiphysis is rarely the primary site of infection in hematogenous osteomyelitis. The epiphyseal plate actually serves as a barrier that is resistant to the spread of infection from the metaphysis.

 

Option B. Growth plate: The growth plate (physis) is typically not affected initially in osteomyelitis. It acts as a barrier to infection spread, though it may become damaged in advanced cases, leading to growth disturbances.

 

Option C. Diaphysis: While the diaphysis can be involved in osteomyelitis, particularly when infection spreads from the metaphysis or in certain conditions like Salmonella osteomyelitis in sickle cell anemia, it is not the primary site of hematogenous osteomyelitis in children.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Hematogenous osteomyelitis in children preferentially affects the metaphysis due to its unique vascular arrangement with hair-pin loop vessels causing blood stasis, creating a favorable environment for bacterial seeding.

questions.text: Low transferrin saturation is seen in: (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Iron deficiency anemia

 

Low transferrin saturation is indicative of inadequate iron within the body to fully saturate transferrin, which is the main protein in the blood that binds to iron and transports it throughout the body. This condition is a hallmark of iron deficiency anemia, where there is a decreased level of total body iron.

 

Transferrin Saturation (%) = (Serum Iron / Total Iron-Binding Capacity) × 100

 

  • Normal: ~20–45%
  • Low: Indicates not enough iron bound to transferrin
  • High: Indicates excess circulating iron

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hemochromatosis: Incorrect because this is characterized by increased iron levels in the body, typically leading to high transferrin saturation.

 

Option C. Thalassemia: Incorrect because this is a genetic disorder that affects the production of hemoglobin, not primarily associated with iron deficiency.

 

Option D. Megaloblastic anemia: Incorrect as this anemia type is usually due to deficiencies in vitamin B12 or folate, not iron.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Low transferrin saturation is a significant marker for diagnosing iron deficiency anemia, reflecting a shortfall in available iron for red blood cell production.

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with a bone marrow aspirate having the finding as shown in the image? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chronic myeloid leukemia

 

The image shows a characteristic cell known as a Gaucher cell, identifiable by its distinctive "crumpled tissue paper" or "wrinkled" cytoplasm appearance and blue staining.

 

 

Gaucher cells are lipid-laden histiocytes seen in Gaucher disease, but similar cells, called pseudo-Gaucher cells, can also be found in hematological malignancies, particularly in chronic myeloid leukemia (CML). In CML, the presence of pseudo-Gaucher cells is a response to increased cellular turnover and abnormal lipid metabolism, making this finding more associated with CML than with other forms of leukemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute myeloid leukemia: While AML may show abnormal blast cells in the bone marrow, it is not typically associated with Gaucher or pseudo-Gaucher cells.

 

Option B. Acute lymphoblastic leukemia: ALL is characterized by lymphoblasts and does not typically present with pseudo-Gaucher cells in the bone marrow.

 

Option D. Chronic lymphocytic leukemia: CLL involves mature lymphocytes, and pseudo-Gaucher cells are not a typical finding in this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pseudo-Gaucher cells, characterized by a crumpled cytoplasm appearance, are often seen in chronic myeloid leukemia due to increased cellular turnover and abnormal lipid metabolism

questions.text: Which of the following bands will increase in serum electrophoresis in Nephrotic syndrome? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Alpha 2 globulin

 

 

  • In Nephrotic syndrome, there is a marked increase in alpha 2 globulin levels on serum electrophoresis. This is due to the liver increasing production of some proteins as a compensatory response to heavy proteinuria, especially proteins like alpha 2 macroglobulin, which are too large to be lost through the glomerulus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gamma globulin: Typically decreased or normal in Nephrotic syndrome due to the loss of smaller immunoglobulins in the urine.

 

Option C. Beta globulin: Generally shows little change in Nephrotic syndrome.

 

Option D. Albumin: Markedly decreased in Nephrotic syndrome due to loss in the urine, which is a hallmark of the disease and responsible for the characteristic edema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Nephrotic syndrome, Alpha 2 globulin increases on serum electrophoresis as a response to heavy proteinuria, while albumin significantly decreases leading to symptoms such as severe swelling and fluid accumulation in the body.

questions.text: A 43-year-old patient with a history of mitral valve replacement on anticoagulation with warfarin is about to undergo hernioplasty for inguinal hernia. What is the target INR prior to surgery? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1.5

 

Explanation

 

Prior to any major surgery, including abdominal surgeries like hernioplasty, it is crucial to manage the patient's anticoagulation status to minimize the risk of excessive bleeding.

 

For patients on warfarin, the target INR should be brought to less than 1.5 before the surgery.

 

This can be achieved by stopping warfarin and administering vitamin K if necessary.

 

If the INR remains above 1.5 on the day of surgery, fresh frozen plasma (FFP) may be administered to rapidly lower the INR. This approach balances the need to prevent excessive bleeding during surgery while managing the risk of thromboembolic complications.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. 0.5-0.8: This range is too low for general surgical preparation and would indicate a significant reversal of anticoagulation, which is not typically required.

 

Option C. 1.5-2: While this range might be acceptable for some minor procedures, major surgeries generally require an INR of less than 1.5 to ensure safety.

 

Option D. 2-3: This range is appropriate for therapeutic anticoagulation but is too high for surgical procedures due to the increased risk of bleeding.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

For patients on warfarin undergoing major surgery, the target INR should be less than 1.5 to minimize bleeding risk.

choices.text: It is a dystonia of the laryngeal muscles.
Standard treatment is with injection of Botulinum Toxin.
Multiple injections of Botulinum toxin are required.
Patients with Abductor Type Dysphonia have a strained and strangled voice.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about spasmodic dysphonia is not true? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Patients with Abductor Type Dysphonia have a strained and strangled voice.

 

Explanation:


This statement is incorrect because patients with Abductor Type Dysphonia actually present with a breathy voice or breathy breaks in voice, not a strained and strangled voice. The strained or strangled voice quality with phonation interruptions and voice breaks is characteristic of Adductor Dysphonia, where the adductor muscles of the larynx go into spasm causing vocal cords to adduct excessively.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is a dystonia of the laryngeal muscles. This is true. Spasmodic dysphonia involves abnormal muscular contractions (spasms) of the laryngeal muscles during speech. The condition can involve either adductor or abductor muscles, causing different voice patterns.

 

Option B. Standard treatment is with injection of Botulinum Toxin. This is true. Botulinum toxin injections are the standard treatment for both adductor and abductor spasmodic dysphonia. In adductor type, injections target the thyroarytenoid muscle, while in abductor type, the posterior cricoarytenoid muscles are injected.

 

Option C. Multiple injections of Botulinum toxin are required. This is true. The benefit of botulinum toxin injections typically lasts only up to 16 weeks, after which repeat injections are needed. This makes it a recurring treatment rather than a one-time solution.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Adductor and Abductor spasmodic dysphonias present with distinctly different voice qualities - strained/strangled in adductor type versus breathy in abductor type - though both are treated with botulinum toxin injections that require periodic repetition due to their temporary effect.

questions.text:
LMN (Lower Motor Neuron) lesion is associated with which one of the following? (INICET NOV 2024)

 

  1. Reduced muscle tone
  2. Spastic paralysis
  3. Babinski sign positive
  4. Fasciculation
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 4

 

Lower motor neuron (LMN) lesions affect the motor neurons in the ventral horn of the spinal cord or their axons in the peripheral nerves. These lesions cause two key features: reduced muscle tone and fasciculation.

 

When there is LMN damage, both alpha and gamma motor neurons are affected. Alpha motor neurons control voluntary muscle contractions, while gamma motor neurons maintain muscle tone. When both are damaged, the patient loses voluntary control of muscles (causing paralysis) and has reduced muscle tone, resulting in flaccid paralysis.

 

Fasciculation is another hallmark of LMN lesions. These are visible, involuntary twitches that occur due to spontaneous discharges from denervated muscle fibers. This phenomenon occurs because of "denervation hypersensitivity" where muscle fibers become hypersensitive after losing their nerve supply.

 

1. Reduced muscle tone: Correct. LMN lesions cause loss of gamma motor neuron activity, which is responsible for maintaining muscle tone. Without this input, muscles become flaccid.

 

4. Fasciculation: Correct. Fasciculations are random, spontaneous contractions of a group of muscle fibers innervated by a single motor unit. They are characteristic of LMN disorders due to denervation hypersensitivity.

 

Other Options:

 

2. Spastic paralysis: Incorrect. Spastic paralysis is characteristic of upper motor neuron (UMN) lesions, not LMN lesions. UMN lesions result in the removal of inhibitory control from higher centers, leading to hyperexcitability of the spinal motor neurons and increased muscle tone. 

 

3. Babinski sign positive: Incorrect. Babinski sign (dorsiflexion of the great toe with fanning of other toes in response to stroking the lateral aspect of the sole) is a pathological reflex seen in UMN lesions, not LMN lesions. It occurs due to the release of the normal flexor plantar response from cortical inhibition.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A patient was brought to casualty with seizures. He had multiple episodes and was taking herbal medicines for the same. He was conscious in between the episodes. During the episodes, he had arching of his back. What is the likely cause? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Strychnine

 

STRYCHNINE NUX VOMICA

 

Active Principle: Strychnine, Brucine

 

Most Toxic part: Seeds (Fatal dose: 1 crushed seed; uncrushed seed not toxic)

 

MOA –

 

  • Competitive antagonist of glycine at post synaptic receptors
  • Strychnine inhibits the uptake of glycine, which is an inhibitory neurotransmitter at post-synaptic junction which gives excitatory effects
  • Spinal Cord: Anterior horn cells & brain stem also.

 

Clinical Presentation –

 

  • Very sudden onset
  • Dramatic presentation
  • “Conscious seizures”
    • Generalized
    • Simultaneous Convulsions (2-3 mins): All muscles affected at once
    • In b/w contractions muscles completely relaxed (5 mins)
      • Death occurs after 5-6 convulsions (1-2 hrs)

 

1. Opisthotonos: Hyper extension of spine

 

2. Emprosthotonus: Forward bending of spine (Sometimes)

 

3. Pleurosthotonus: Sideways bending of spine (Sometimes)

 

4. Risus Sardonicus: Contraction of facial muscles leading to smiling face

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: Ricinus communis (Castor) poisoning leads to burning pain in throat, vomiting, abdominal pain, and diarrhea and death.

 

Option C: Nerium odorum (cardiac poison) causes headache, dizziness, vomiting, low blood pressure, fibrillation, AV block, coma, and death can occur due to cardiac failure.

 

Option D: Datura poisoning show symptoms like

 

  • Dry hot skin
  • Dilatation of pupils
  • Diplopia
  • Dry mouth
  • Dysphagia
  • Dysarthria
  • Drunken gait
  • Delirium
  • Drowsiness
  • Death due to respiratory or cardiac failure

 

Educational Objective:

 

Strychnine poisoning presents with characteristic "conscious seizures" and back arching (opisthotonos) due to its antagonistic action on glycine receptors.

questions.text: Which gene defect causes familial hyperlipidemia? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) LDLr

 

Familial hyperlipidemia, particularly familial hypercholesterolemia (FH), is a genetic disorder characterized by high levels of low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol in the blood. The primary cause of this condition is mutations in the LDL receptor (LDLr) gene.

 

Mechanism of Action: The LDL receptor is responsible for the uptake of LDL cholesterol from the blood into the liver. When there are mutations in the LDLr gene, the receptors are either dysfunctional or deficient. As a result, LDL cholesterol cannot be effectively removed from the bloodstream, leading to elevated levels of LDL cholesterol. This condition significantly increases the risk of atherosclerosis and cardiovascular diseases.

 

  • Heterozygous FH: This form is more common and results in moderately high LDL cholesterol levels (200-300 mg/dL). It is associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular diseases.
  • Homozygous FH: This form is rarer and more severe, with LDL cholesterol levels potentially reaching 600-700 mg/dL. Individuals with homozygous FH have a very high risk of early cardiovascular events and death.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ApoE:  Mutations in the ApoE gene cause familial dysbetalipoproteinemia (Type III hyperlipoproteinemia in Frederickson classification), which leads to elevated levels of intermediate-density lipoproteins (IDL) and is characterized by the presence of remnant particles in the blood.

 

Option B. ApoCII:  Deficiency in ApoCII causes familial chylomicronemia syndrome (Type I hyperlipoproteinemia in Frederickson classification). This condition is associated with extremely high levels of triglycerides due to impaired lipoprotein lipase (LPL) activation, which is necessary for the breakdown of triglycerides.

 

Option D. ApoB48:  ApoB48 is involved in the assembly and secretion of chylomicrons from the intestine. There is no known condition caused by a deficiency of ApoB48 that leads to familial hyperlipidemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mutations in the LDL receptor (LDLr) gene cause familial hypercholesterolemia, a condition characterized by high levels of LDL cholesterol in the blood due to impaired clearance by the liver. This condition significantly increases the risk of cardiovascular diseases.

questions.text: There were 4000 live births in a community in a year. Do MMR Calculation if you come to know that 6 women died during pregnancy, labor/delivery, or within 42 days of delivery - 2 due to Obstructed labor, 1 due to Sepsis, 1 due to PPH, 1 due to Snake bite and 1 due to electrocution. [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) 100

 

The Maternal Mortality Ratio (MMR) is calculated using the formula:

 

 

In this scenario, there were 4000 live births in the community.

 

Calculation of Maternal Deaths:

 

  • Maternal death is defined as the death of a woman during pregnancy, labor, or within 42 days of termination of pregnancy, provided the death is related to maternity or its complications.
  • Out of the 6 reported deaths:
    • 2 deaths due to Obstructed labor (included)
    • 1 death due to Sepsis (included)
    • 1 death due to PPH (Postpartum Hemorrhage) (included)
    • 1 death due to Snake bite (not related to maternity, hence excluded)
    • 1 death due to Electrocution (not related to maternity, hence excluded)

 

Therefore, only 4 deaths are considered maternal deaths.
